text: No man is an island, entire of itself; every man is a piece of the continent.
author: John Donne

text: No spring nor summer's beauty hath such grace as I have seen in one Autumnal face.
author: John Donne

text: No spring nor summer beauty hath such grace, As I have seen in one autumnal face.

text: To be no part of any body, is to be nothing.
author: John Donne

text: No man is an island, entire of itself; every man is a piece of the continent, a part of the main.
author: John Donne

text: Love, all alike, no season knows, nor clime, nor hours, days, months, which are the rags of time.
author: John Donne

text: Our fear of death is like our fear that summer will be short, but when we have had our swing of pleasure, our fill of fruit, and our swelter of heat, we say we have had our day.
author: John Donne

text: Tears are the summer shower to the soul.
author: John Donne

text: Any man's death diminishes me, because I am involved in Mankind; And therefore never send to know for whom the bell tolls; it tolls for thee.
author: John Donne

text: Come live with me, and be my love, and we will some new pleasures prove, of golden sands, and crystal brooks, with silken lines and silver hooks.
author: John Donne

text: Nature's great masterpiece, an elephant; the only harmless great thing.
author: John Donne

text: No man is an island, entire of itself.
author: John Donne

text: Eternity is not an everlasting flux of time, but time is as a short parenthesis in a long period; and eternity had been the same as it is, though time had never been.
author: John Donne

text: Pleasure is none, if not diversified.
author: John Donne

text: No spring nor summer beauty hath such grace as I have seen in one autumnal face.
author: John Donne

text: Humiliation is the beginning of sanctification.
author: John Donne

text: Death is an ascension to a better library.
author: John Donne

text: When one man dies, one chapter is not torn out of the book, but translated into a better language.
author: John Donne

text: Storms chafe, and soon wear out themselves, or us; . In calms, Heaven laughs to see us languish thus.

text: Death be not proud thou some have called thee. Mighty and dreadful for thou art not so.

text: Despair is the damp of hell, as joy is the serenity of heaven.

text: I observe the physician with the same diligence as the disease.
author: John Donne

text: Happiness can improve every child's looks. Happiness can make children eager and interested. Happiness and goof health can go hand in hand. Happiness improves children's relationships with friends and family.

text: All divinity is love, or wonder.
